_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Chlorine leak detectors are inspected and tested monthly.Chlorinators inspected quarterly. Hourly checks of the chlorination system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION:
The City of Cape Girardeau, Missouri (City) operates a 7.5-million gallon day, public water supply treatment plant, Cape Rock Treatment Plant (Plant). This Risk Management Plan (RMP) fulfills the requirements of the Clean Air Act's Section 112( r ) for the chlorination system at the Plant.

PLANT DESCRIPION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The Plant uses one regulated substance, chlorine, for disinfection to make the treated water safe for human consumption.  A maximum of eighteen (18) 2,000 pound chlorine containers are stored and used inside the new chlorination room of the Plant. A maximum of three (3) ton chlorine containers are used in the process. This RMP addresses the storage, management, and use of the chlorine containers and delivery system. 

The Plant is located at 20 East Cape Rock Drive, Cape Girardeau, Missouri.  It is on a bluff overlooking the river.  The surrounding area is residential.  Alliance Water Resources operates the Plant for the City.

THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO:
The worst-case scenario for a chlorine release at the Plant was determined to be the complete discharge of a full 2,000-pound chlorine cylinder in 10 minutes.  This is in accordance with the definition provided in the United States Environmental Protection (EPA) guidance for RMP development.  The release would be inside the chlorine room but there will be no response to reduce the effect of the release.  The conditions of the scenario such as time, weather and windspeed are those given in EPA's  Off-Site Consequence Guidance.  The area of potential impact from the chlorine release was determined using RMP*Comp.  The modeling software developed by the United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the EPA for this determination.  

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO
The alternative release scenario is, by definition, a more likely release scenario than the worst-case.  A more likely scenario for a chlorine release at the Plant that might have an off

site effect is the leaking of a chlorine line from the chlorine container or the supply regulator at the container.  The release would be inside the chlorine room.  The alternate release case was assumed to be the failure of the lowest fusible link on the chlorine tank. A 1 in diameter hole was assumed with 12 in liquid height. The release was assumed to be in an enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air. Active mitigation includes a scrubber system and automated vacuum system, with 90% release reduction used. 30 min release was assumed based on team knowledge of operational response rate. All calculations were performed with RMP*Comp


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
The plant has operation, maintenance, and inspection procedures designed to review the chlorination system routinely.  Personnel receive significant training before being allowed to work on the chlorination systems. 

At the beginning and end of the daily operating period, and as each container is changed, the valves and piping are tested for leaks.  There are operating procedures for startup, shutdown, normal operation, and emergency operations.  Personnel are trained routinely on safety concerns and general operation procedures as well as emergency procedures.  

The chlorination room is equipped with chlorine detectors and alarms that would sound if a leak occurred.  The system is a vacuum feed system with automatic shutoff valves in the case of a loss of vacuum due to a line break or clogging.  There is a scrubber system linked to the chlorine detector that would mitigate a release inside the new chlorine storage room.  Ventilation is provided in the chlorination room only when a worker is present.  Remote ventilation system shutoffs are also provided in the chlorine storage and processing room. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 
The Plant has not had a significant chlorine release in the past 5 years. 3 incident investigations were documented, though only residual releases occurred relat

ed to maintenance for the incidents.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
In an event of an emergency involving any release of chlorine at the Plant, the fire department will be called to handle the response. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
There are no planned changes to improve safety at this time.
